transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient continues to experience persistent feelings of fatigue, frustration, and hopelessness despite some improvement with grounding exercises.

evidence.text: You mentioned that these have helped a little, but some days still feel very tough, and you experience feelings of fatigue, frustration, and hopelessness.
But honestly, on some days, I still feel really tired and down, like nothing is changing much.

transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient reports difficulty consistently using coping strategies such as journaling and reminders due to feeling overwhelmed or forgetting.

evidence.text: I try to use the reminders and journal, but I forget or just feel too overwhelmed to do it.

transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient frequently experiences negative self-evaluative thoughts, including beliefs of not being good enough, being a failure, and fears of never catching up or doing well enough.

evidence.text: when I feel really tired and down, I start thinking that I’m just not good enough. Like, no matter what I do, I still mess up or fall behind. Sometimes I feel like I’m a failure, and that I’ll never catch up or do well enough.

transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient experiences physical symptoms associated with distress, including heaviness in the chest, anxiety, upset stomach, numbness, and cognitive fog.

evidence.text: Yeah, I think I feel a kind of heaviness in my chest, like a weight pressing down. Sometimes I get really anxious, and my stomach feels upset. I also feel kind of numb, like I don’t really feel anything, even when I try to focus or do my work. It’s like my mind is just blank or foggy.

transcript_facts.fact_text: Academic pressures, concerns about family, and poor sleep are identified as triggers that worsen the patient's distress and negative thoughts.

evidence.text: when I have a lot of assignments due or if I think about my family and how I can't support them enough, it gets worse. Also, if I don’t sleep well, everything feels more intense. Sometimes, just thinking about failing or disappointing people makes me feel even more anxious and tired.

transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient holds perfectionistic beliefs and fears of disappointing others, particularly family, which contribute to her distress.

evidence.text: I just feel like I have to be perfect all the time, or I’ll let everyone down. But maybe those thoughts aren’t entirely true. I don’t know how to change them, though.
I worry that I’ll disappoint my family or make them ashamed. Sometimes I feel like I’m just not cut out for this, and I wonder if I should just give up.

transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient expresses a sense of lack of control over her thoughts and feelings, describing them as persistent and difficult to manage.

evidence.text: Sometimes I just don’t know how to stop those thoughts from taking over. It’s like they’re always there, and I can’t get away from them.
Sometimes I feel like I don’t have any control over these feelings, so any tips would be helpful.

transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient finds grounding exercises, such as the 5-4-3-2-1 technique, somewhat helpful in reducing feelings of overwhelm and bringing a sense of calm.

evidence.text: The grounding exercises do help me feel a bit calmer, especially when I remember to do them.
It’s kind of calming to just notice these things. I didn’t realize how much I was missing by not paying attention to the present.
I think I’d like to keep practicing this. It feels a little better when I focus on what’s around me instead of my thoughts. Maybe I can do this when I start feeling overwhelmed again.

transcript_facts.fact_text: The patient sets goals to use grounding exercises more regularly, resume journaling, and improve her understanding and management of her feelings, as well as to increase her energy and focus.

evidence.text: I think I want to try using the grounding exercise more when I feel really anxious or sad. Maybe I can also journal about my thoughts and feelings, like I used to. I’d like to understand my feelings better and find ways to handle them without feeling so overwhelmed. I hope I can get a little more energy and focus, too.
